[[File:Egy sag.png|thumb|left|Protesters removing portraits of Ex-president Mubarak in Sohag City in upper Egypt]]
 
[[Cairo]] has been at the epicentre of much of the crisis. The largest protests were held in downtown [[Tahrir Square]], which was considered the "protest movementâs beating heart and most effective symbol."<ref>{{cite web|author=Al Jazeera online producer |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/spotlight/anger-in-egypt/2011/02/20112811181499676.html |title=The different shades of Tahrir - Anger in Egypt |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=9 February 2011}}</ref> On the first three days of the protests, there were clashes between the central security police and protesters and as of 28 January, police forces withdrew from most of Cairo. Citizens then formed neighbourhood watch groups to keep the order as widespread looting was reported. Traffic police were reintroduced to Cairo on the morning of 31 January.<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/01/31/AR2011013102845.html|title=Egypt Unrest and Protests Continue as Police Return to Cairo Streets|work=[[The Washington Post]] |date=|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> Estimated 2 million people protested at Tahrir square.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cnewsworld.com/world-news/middle-east-world-news/estimated-2-million-people-protest-in-_-around-tahrir-square-in-cairo-egypt-mp4/ |title=Estimated 2 Million People Protest In _ Around Tahrir Square In Cairo Egypt.mp4 | Current News World Web Source for News and Information |publisher=Cnewsworld.com |date= |accessdate=20 February 2011}}</ref>
[[Cairo]] has been at the epicentre of much of the crisis. The largest protests were held in downtown [[Tahrir Square]], which was considered the "protest movementâs beating heart and most effective symbol."<ref>{{cite web|author=Al Jazeera online producer |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/spotlight/anger-in-egypt/2011/02/20112811181499676.html |title=The different shades of Tahrir - Anger in Egypt |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=9 February 2011}}</ref> On the first three days of the protests, there were clashes between the central security police and protesters and as of 28 January, police forces withdrew from most of Cairo. Citizens then formed neighbourhood watch groups to keep the order as widespread looting was reported. Traffic police were reintroduced to Cairo on the morning of 31 January.<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/01/31/AR2011013102845.html|title=Egypt Unrest and Protests Continue as Police Return to Cairo Streets|work=[[The Washington Post]] |date=|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> Estimated 2 million people protested at Tahrir square.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cnewsworld.com/world-news/middle-east-world-news/estimated-2-million-people-protest-in-_-around-tahrir-square-in-cairo-egypt-mp4/ |title=Estimated 2 Million People Protest In _ Around Tahrir Square In Cairo Egypt.mp4 | Current News World Web Source for News and Information |publisher=Cnewsworld.com |date= |accessdate=20 February 2011}}</ref>
